for_sales.sales_text:
Once used only for local East Coast cruising she has been extensively brought up to a standard for longer cruises including Round Britain, North Sea crossings and Brest and Douarnenez. Her sailing characteristics have endeared her to successive owners and she points to wind like a 'witch'..

Engine

  • Sabb 2H - 1972 model * Installed 2017. Ship's lifeboat engine so little use.

Rig

  • All sails by James Lawrence. Hand finished cringles and bolt ropes * Main, Staysail, Jib, Cruising Chute with snuffer * Roller boom reefing * Foresails on Wykeham Martin furling

Hull

  • Pitch pine on oak frames * Re-caulked below water line 2015 * Keel bolts removed and checked, two replaced 2017 * Deck sealed with Coelan * Whale double action hand bilge pump in stern locker

Navigation

  • Nav station desk with chart table * Raymarine ST60 network - Depth, Fluxgate compass, Anenometer, Tridata, Autohelm. * Garmin Chartplotter GPSmap 700 series linked to NASA AIS receiver * Garmin GPS152 linked to Standard Horizon 3500 VHF with full cockpit control unit * Nav lights port and starboard in converted traditional lanterns with coloured LED

Shore Power and batteries

  • Shore power hidden in starboard cockpit lockers. * Hager consumer unit with trip switches to mains socket and battery charger * Zinc Guard unit * Xantrex smart battery charger * New engine battery * Two 110ah leisure batteries * Two Solbian solar panels mounted on cabin top to smart controller * 12v to 240v inverter linked to single socket * Automatic bilge pump on always on circuit

Galley

  • Techimpex 2 burner, grill and oven on gimbals. * Stainless steel gas locker in stern deck vented through the transom * Built in fridge * Sink and drainer with hand pump tap * Taylors paraffin pressure stove * LED bulbs in all internal lights * Red lights for galley and nav station for night sailing * Baby Blake heads * Two large stainless steel water tanks

Ancillary Equipment

  • Liferaft in soft bag; needs servicing * Avon Redcrest * Mahogany boarding ladder * Six fenders * Mooring ropes * Boat hooks * CQR 35 main anchor with 70 metres of chain * CQR kedge anchor and warp * 2 piece windsurf mast for poling out the cruising chute * Assorted buckets and spare diesel cans * Oil vacuum pump

Witch was built by Dickies of Tarbert as the private ferry yacht for the Laird of Gigha in 1898. Her full history is known and she has been well cared for over the years. Her structure is mostly original and she has recently had her below the waterline caulking raked and replaced with traditional cotton and red lead stopping. Below decks she was re-fitted in 1918 and then again in 1963. This latter was not comfortable and was replaced with a standard layout with galley and nav station in 2007.

boat.full_description:
Built by A M Dickie of Tarbert for William James Yorke Scarlett, the Laird of Gigha, she was named Belem after the French three masted barque which was famous for its speed. Used principally as a ferry to and from the mainland, she was originally flush-decked with the skylight set in the deck. Her design is quite advanced for the time with her three-quarter length keel and cutaway stem. In 1918 she had the coachroof added which adds significantly to the headroom.

In 2013, she took part in the OGA Round Britain Challenge, visit Sailing by and the Witch website for more details.
boat.name: Witch

ownerships.name: William James Yorke Scarlett The Laird Of Gigha

boat.short_description: Witch, a gaff-rigged cutter, is a yacht originally built as a ferry in 1898 for the Laird of Gigha on the western isles of Scotland.
